utterance: 'It's extraordinary navigation, certainly,'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'Oh, mem, if you please, isn't it better than the hother?'
speaker: Meadows

utterance: 'I don't mind being 'umped-up on the bank, miss, if you please,'
speaker: Meadows

utterance: those great waves we 'ad last week, mem, if you please, that seemed so horful.'
speaker: Meadows

utterance: 'I am sorry you will have to see them again so soon,'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: ' and not all this grass!'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'I don't see how we are to get on here at all at night,'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'What is that, captain?'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'That? Jupiter Light.'
speaker: the captain

utterance: 'Then we must be near Warwick?'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'The next landing is War-wick,'
speaker: the captain

utterance: 'So near?'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'No hurry. Ain't there yet.'
speaker: the captain

utterance: 'It isn't much of a place, then?'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'Place? Post-office and Romney; that's all. Slacken off that line there-you hear? Slacken, I tell you!'
speaker: the captain

utterance: 'Is this Cicely?'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'Yes, I am Cicely.'
speaker: Cicely

utterance: 'Are those your trunks? Oh, you have brought some one with you?'
speaker: Cicely

utterance: 'It's only Meadows, my maid; she goes back to-morrow when the boat returns.'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'There's room for her, if you mean that; the house is large enough for anything. I was only wondering what our people would make of her; they have never seen a white servant in their lives.'
speaker: Cicely

utterance: 'You didn't bring the baby?'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'Jack? Oh, no; Jack's asleep.'
speaker: Cicely

utterance: ' Are you cold?'
speaker: Cicely

utterance: 'We'll start as soon as that hissing boat gets off. I hope you don't mind riding behind a mule? Oh, look! Uncle Abram is shocked that your maidwhat did you call her-Fields ?-should be carrying anything-a white lady as he supposes; and he is trying to take the bag away from her. She's evidently frightened; Pomp and Plato haven't as many clothes on as they might have, I acknowledge. Oh, do look!'
speaker: Cicely

utterance: 'I didn't expect anything half so funny,'
speaker: Cicely

utterance: 'This is the sea-shore, isn't it?'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'Oh, no; this isn't the sea; this is the Sound,'
speaker: Cicely

utterance: The sea is round on the other side. You will hear it often enough at Romney; it booms dreadfully after a storm.'
speaker: Cicely

utterance: 'Will you get in, please?'
speaker: Cicely

utterance: 'Meadows! Meadows!'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'Never mind the luggage; it is quite safe. You are to come with us in this waggon.'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'Yes, mem,'
speaker: Meadows

utterance: 'And shall I bring the dressing-bags with me, mem?'
speaker: Meadows

utterance: 'She is bringing them whether or no,'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'I knew she would. She likes to pretend that one contains a gold-mounted dressing-case and the other a jewel-casket; she is accustomed to such things, and considers them the proper appendages of a lady.'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'Meadows, put down those bags,'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'they are too heavy for you; but not too near Mrs. Bruce-to trouble her.'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'Hiyi!'
speaker: Uncle Abram

utterance: 'All ri', den, ef yer wanter,'
speaker: Uncle Abram

utterance: Lippity-clip!'
speaker: Uncle Abram

utterance:
'I'd better tell you now, so that you won't call me that again
-before the others: I'm not Mrs. Bruce any longer; my name is Morrison. I married Ferdinand Morrison six months ago.'
speaker: Cicely

utterance: 'Bring the steps, some of you.'
speaker: Cicely

utterance: 'Here is Eve,'
speaker: Cicely

utterance: 'Grandpa,'
speaker: Cicely

utterance: 'and Aunt Sabrina.'
speaker: Cicely

utterance: 'My father, Judge Abercrombie,'
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: 'You are very welcome, my dear. But how cold your hands are, even through your gloves! Dilsey, make a fire.'
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: 'I am not cold,'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'It is nothing,'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'I am perfectly well,'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'It has been a long voyage, and that, you know, is tiresome. But now that it is over, I shall soon be myself again, and able to continue my journey.'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'Continue! Are you going any further, then?'
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: 'I had hoped-we have all hoped that you would spend a long time with us.'
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: 'You are very kind. It will be impossible,'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'Thanks; I will not take it off now. Later, when I go to my room.'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'There he is,'
speaker: Cicely

utterance: 'there's your little Jack. He knows you; I have talked to him about you scores of times.'
speaker: Cicely

utterance: 'Auntie?'
speaker: little Jack

utterance: 'Ess; Aunty Eve!'
speaker: little Jack

utterance: 'He is the image of Jack!'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'Yes, I know it,'
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: 'And I knew how it would affect you, my dear. But I think it is a comfort that he does look like him; don't you? And now you must not talk any more about going away, but stay here with us and love him.'
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: 'Stay!'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'Do you think she would give him to me?'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'She cannot care for him-not as I do.'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance:
'Give up her child-her own child? My niece?
I think not; I certainly think not.'
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance:
'Then I shall take him from her, and you must help me. What will she care in a month from now-a year?
She has already forgotten his father.'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'The simplest way would be to stay here for the present,'
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: 'Stay here? Now? How can you ask it?'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance:
'It's a desolate place now, I know; but it's very peaceful. The garden is pretty. And we hoped that you wouldn't mind. We even hoped that you would like it a little-the child being here. We would do all we could.
Of course I know it isn't much.'
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: 'Do you think I can stand seeing him,'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: here-in Jack's place? If I could, I would go to-night.'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'O Jack-Jack--'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'You mean Mr. Morrison ?'
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: 'You didn't know, then? Cicely didn't tell you?'
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: 'She told me that she had married again--nothing more— six months ago. She let me come here-you let me come here without knowing it.'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'Oh, I thought you knew it,'
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: 'I did not like the marriage myself, Miss Bruce; I assure you I did not. I was very fond of John, and it seemed too sudden. If she had only waited the year-and two years would have been so much more appropriate. I go there very often-to John's grave-indeed I do; it is as dear to me as the graves of my own family, and I keep the grass cut very carefully; I will show you. You remember when I wrote you that second time? I feared it then, though I was not sure, and I tried to prepare you a little by saying that the baby was now your chief interest, naturally. And he wasn't going to be married,'
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: at least, not that we knew. I did not say more, because I was not sure, Miss Bruce. But after it had really happened, I supposed of course that Cicely wrote to you.'
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: 'She!'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'But Mr. Morrison is not here; he is not here, and never has been. She met him in Savannah, and married him there; it was at a cousin's. But she only stayed with him for a few months, and we fear that it is not a very happy marriage. He is in South America at present, and you know how far away that is. I haven't the least idea when he is coming back.'
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: 'Of course we don't know that it is an unhappy marriage; but as she came back to us so soon, it struck us so-it made that impression; wouldn't it have made the same upon you? She must have suffered extremely, and so we ought to be doubly kind to her,'
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: 'I am not likely to be unkind as long as there is the slightest hope of getting this child away from her,'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'For she is the mother, isn't she? She couldn't very well have palmed off some other baby on you, for Jack himself was here then, I know. Oh, you needn't be afraid, I shall defer to her, yield to her, grovel to her!'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: 'Supper is ready.'
speaker: Cicely

utterance: 'You'll have to let her go; she puts out her mouth so !'
speaker: Mrs. Mason

utterance: 'I can't stand it any longer, Eve; I am going home. Fortunately you are provided for, or I couldn't. I shall lose my place here, of course; but I don't care. Go I must.'
speaker: Jack

utterance: 'Blood will tell,'
speaker: Jack's father's regimental companions

utterance: I don't know that I have ever been tired, exactly.
speaker: Cicely

utterance: She has always been the same, except that since her second marriage she is much more quiet.
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: Until then she was like quicksilver, she used to run through the thickets so swiftly that no one could follow her, and she used to play ball by the hou with-
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: With Jack.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: little Rupert,
speaker: Cicely

utterance: O Eve, it is Ferdinand, and I did not know him!
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: How could you expect to know me, when you have never seen me in your life?
speaker: Ferdinand Morrison

utterance: But we have your picture. I ought to have known
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: My dear aunt, never accuse yourself; your best friends will always do that for you. I dare say my picture doesn't half do me justice.
speaker: Ferdinand Morrison

utterance: This is Cicely's sister, Eve. She has come out—so kindly-from England to pay us a visit.
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: Such a surprise! So nice! so delightful! How little we thought this morning, when we rose as usual, and everything was the same-how little we thought that it would be such a sweet, such a happy day!
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: There, auntie, now we've made acquaintance; you must take me in as a genuine nephew, and improve me.
speaker: Ferdinand Morrison

utterance: Oh, improve.
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: Can I speak to you for a moment, Cicely?
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: Oh, yes. What is it?
speaker: Cicely

utterance: You said he would not come here.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: Oh! he never would do it for me before, though I asked him, and asked him, and yet he has done it now! Think of that!
speaker: Cicely

utterance: Have you forgotten all you said that night at Mrs. Cray's?
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: Yes.
speaker: Cicely

utterance: Yes, I have forgotten the whole!
speaker: Cicely

utterance: Nothing will happen, Eve; you needn't be afraid.
speaker: Cicely

utterance: Has he told you so?
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: Oh, we never speak of it. Did you think we spoke of 6 it-of such a thing as that? A husband and wife-people 77 who love each other? But you needn't be troubled; it's over for ever.
speaker: Cicely

utterance: I ran after you to say that I hope that you will have, some day, as much happiness as mine.
speaker: Cicely

utterance: My dear, you are growing paler.
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: Perhaps this sea-air of ours is not good for you.
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: You are right; it is not; all the same, I will stay awhile longer, if you will let me.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: Oh, my dear-when we want you to live here!
speaker: Miss Abercrombie

utterance: Perhaps I shall die here.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: Eve!
speaker: Cicely

utterance: Help me to dress Jack.
speaker: Cicely

utterance: Are you going to take him out of the house?
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: Yes.
speaker: Cicely

utterance: Where is he?
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: Outside-out of the house for the moment; but he will come back; and then, if he comes down this hall, we must escape.
speaker: Cicely

utterance: Where? We must have the same ideas, you know.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: I thought we could go through the ballroom, and out by the north wing.
speaker: Cicely

utterance: And once outside?
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: We must hide.
speaker: Cicely

utterance: But where?
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: In the thicket.
speaker: Cicely

utterance: It isn't a very large space. Supposing Jack should cry?
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: I can't talk!
speaker: Cicely

utterance: You needn't; I'll take care of you!
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: Come.
speaker: Cicely

utterance: Now we can run.
speaker: Cicely

utterance: Hurry!
speaker: Cicely

utterance: He will go through the whole thicket, now that he has the idea.
speaker: Cicely

utterance: There's no thicket there; and if he comes, there's a boat.
speaker: Cicely

utterance: Shouldn't you be safer, after all, in the house? And oughtn't we to think of Miss Sabrina?
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: No, he won't touch her, he is thinking only of us. This time he is determined to kill us; he fancies that I am some one else, a woman who is going to attack his wife; and he thinks that Jack is some other child, who has injured his Jack.
speaker: Cicely

utterance: He shall never touch Jack! Give him to me, Cicely; he is too heavy for you.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: I will not give him to any one-any one.
speaker: Cicely

utterance: What is that on your throat, and down the front of your dress?
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: It's wet. Why, it's blood!
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: Yes; I am cut here a little. I suppose it has begun to bleed again. He has a knife to-night. That is what makes me so afraid.
speaker: Cicely

utterance: Get into the boat and push off, don't wait for me; I'm in no danger.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: He is not hurt; at least not seriously.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: Yes, darling.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: Da-a-a-m your fortune!
speaker: Judge Abercrombie

utterance:
There, now; we are awful Yankees up here, all of us, I'm afraid; for ever thinking of bargains.
Fact is, we ain't high-minded. You can't be, if you are forever eating salt pork.
speaker: Hollis

utterance: At the battle of the Nile I was there all the while; I was there all the while at the battle of the Nile.
speaker: Hollis

utterance:
Hello, isn't that Miss Bruce coming down the beach?
Yes, sure-ly; I know her by the way she carries her head.
speaker: Hollis

utterance: It is time to return, I reckon.
speaker: Judge Abercrombie

utterance: She won't think us very polite, skedaddling off in this fashion.
speaker: Hollis

utterance: She's a tip-top walker, isn't she? I see her coming in almost every day from 'way out somewhere-she doesn't mind how far. Our ladies here don't walk much; they don't seem to find it interesting; but Miss Bruce, now--she says the woods are beautiful. Can't say I have found 'em so myself.
speaker: Hollis

utterance: Have you had any new cases lately?
speaker: Judge Abercrombie

utterance: Did that Paul tell you I was a lawyer? Was once, but have given up practising. I've got an Auction and Commission store now; never took you there because business hasn't been flourishing; sometimes for days together there's been nothing but the skeleton.
speaker: Hollis

utterance:
I don't mean myself! Say, now, did you really think I meant myself?
No, this is at real one; it was left with me over a year ago to be sold on commission-medical students, or a college, you know.
Man never came back-perhaps he's a skeleton himself in the lake somewhere-so there it hangs still; first-class, and in elegant condition. To-day there are six bonnets to keep it company; so we 're full.
speaker: Hollis

utterance: I saw you walking in from the Park, so I came across to join you.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: You don't mind a longish walk, do you? You look splendid.
speaker: Hollis

utterance: We need not take you further, Mr. Hollis. Your time must be valuable to you.
speaker: Judge Abercrombie

utterance: Not a bit; there's no demand to-day for the bonnetsunless the skeleton wants to wear 'em.
speaker: Hollis

utterance: Is it an exhibition?
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: It's my store-Auction and Commission. Not crowded. It's round the next corner; want to go in ?
speaker: Hollis

utterance: By all means.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance:
Here are the bonnets. They may have to go out to the mines. You see, it 's part of a bankrupt stock.
Not but what they ain't first-class-remarkably so.
speaker: Hollis

utterance: Are you trying to make Miss Bruce buy that old rubbish?
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: Old? Why, Paul, I dare say this here bonnet was made in Detroit not later than one year ago.
speaker: Hollis

utterance: If I cannot buy it myself, I might take it out to the mines for you, Mr. Hollis, and sell it to the women there; I might take out all six.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: You'd do it a heap better than I could.
speaker: Hollis

utterance: Let me see, I can try.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: What an effect!
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: Whatever the rest of you may do, I must be going.
speaker: Judge Abercrombie

utterance: So must I. Wait until I put back the bonnets.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: I was on my way home, and I suppose you were too? Hollis, won't you come along?
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: Jupiter Light.
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: It's a lighthouse on a bad reef out there.
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: There's a Jupiter Light on Abercrombie Island, too.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: It's a common enough name; the best-known one is off the coast of Florida.
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: They're right; we shall be late for the steamer if we don't look out. You can help now if you like, Kit.
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: At the battle of the Nile I was there all the while
speaker: Hollis

utterance: Are you really going to bed so early?
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: I am in bed already.
speaker: Cicely

utterance: Do you want anything? Isn't there something I can bring you?
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: No.
speaker: Cicely

utterance: Is that you? I thought there would be no one here.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: We are the only passengers; but, as there are six of us, you cannot quite control us all.
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 1 control no one.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: You will have the place to yourself in a few moments, because I shall turn in soon; the time to finish this cigar-if you don't mind the smoke?
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: No, I don't mind.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: Hasn't it been jolly? I do love to be out like this, away from all bother.
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: Do you? I thought you didn't.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: It's very good for Cicely too; I wish I could take her oftener. Her promise to stay on here weighs upon her so heavily! I don't know whether she would have kept her word with me or not; but you know, of course, that Ferdie himself has written, telling her that she must stay?
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: No.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: She didn't tell you?
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: She tells me nothing! If she would only allow it, I would go down to Romney to-morrow. I could be the nurse; I could be the housekeeper; anything.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: You're not needed down there, they have plenty of people; we want you here, to see to her.
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: One or the other of them;-I hope they will always permit it. I can be of use, perhaps, about Jack.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: You are too humble, Miss Bruce; sometimes you seem to be almost on your knees to Cicely, as though you had done her some great wrong. The truth is the other way; she ought to be on her knees to you. You brought her off when she hadn't the force to come herself, poor little woman! And you did it boldly and quickly, just as a man would have done it. Now that I know you, I can imagine the whole thing.
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: Never speak of that time-never.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: Well, I won't, then, if you don't like it. But you will let me say how glad I am that you intend to remain with her, at least for a while. You will see from this that I don't believe a word of her story about your dislike for my brother.
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: There is nothing I would not do for him!
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: Yes, you like to do things; to be active. They tell me that you are fond of having your own way; but that is the very sort of person they need--a woman like you, strong and cool. After a while you would really like Ferdie, you couldn't help it, and he would like you.
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: It is impossible that he should like me.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance:
You're going in? Well, fifteen hours in the open air are an opiate. Should you care to go forward first, for a moment? I can show you a place where you can look down below: there are two hundred emigrants on board
-Norwegians.
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: Take my arm; I can guide you better so. It's dark, and I know the ins and outs.
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: I don't want you to be falling down!
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: I like your friend Mr. Hollis so much!
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: Yes, Kit is a wonderful fellow; he has extraordinary talent.
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: Oh, extraordinary!
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: If you don't think so, it's because you don't know him. He is an excellent classical scholar, to begin with; he has read everything under the sun; he is an inventor, a geologist, and one of the best lawyers in the state, in spite of his notion about not practising.
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: You don't add that he is an excellent auctioneer?
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: No; that he is not, I am sorry to say; he is a very bad one.
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance:
Yet it is the occupation which he has himself selected.
Does that show such remarkable talent? Now you, with your mining'
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: I didn't select mining, and I'm not particularly good at it; I took what I could get, that's all.
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: This T. P. Mayhew is an excellent boat. But, as to that, all the N. T. boats are good.
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: N. T.?
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: Northern Transportation.
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: Tell me about your iron.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: It isn't mine-I wish it was; I'm only manager.
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: I don't mean the mine near Port aux Pins; I mean your Clay County iron.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: What do you know about that?
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: Mr. Hollis told me; he said you had declined an excellent offer, and he was greatly concerned about it; he told me the reasons why he did not agree with you.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: It must have been interesting! But that all happened some time ago; didn't you know that he had come round to my view of it, after all?
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: No.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: Yes, round he came; it took him eight days. He has got such a look-on-all-sides head that, when he starts out to investigate, he tramps all over the sky; if he intends to go north, he goes east, west, and south first, so as to make sure that these are not the right directions. However, on the eighth day in he came, squeezing himself through a crack, as usual, and explained to me at length the reasons why it was better, on the whole, to decline that offer. He had thought the matter out to its remotest contingencies-some of them went over into the next century! It was remarkably clear and well argued ; and of course very satisfactory to me.
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: But in the meantime you had already declined, hadn't you?
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: Yes; but it was a splendid piece of following up. declare, I always feel my inferiority when I am with people who can really talk-talk like that!
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: Oh!
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: Don't be vexed. I was only laughing to see how———
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: How what?
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: How invariably you women flatter.
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: I don't.
speaker: Miss Bruce

utterance: You had better learn, then, I'm afraid that when we're well stuffed with it, we 're more good-natured. Shall I take you back to the stern? I'm getting frightfully sleepy; aren't you?
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: Good-night,
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: You had better see that the windows are closed. There's going to be a change of wind.
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'Is she-is she alive?'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'I don't believe she has repented!'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'See here! that is what I have come for; all these months she has thought so, but it is a mistake; he died from another cause.'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'Thank God!'
speaker: Mr. Smith

utterance: 'Thank God, and bring her out, man! She is the one to know."
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'I'll do what I can, but it may not be thought best by those in authority; I must warn you that I shall obey the orders of my superior, in any case.'
speaker: Mr. Smith

utterance: 'Yet you don't look like an ass!'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'Wait here, please,'
speaker: Mr. Smith

utterance: 'Mr. Smith?'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'Fuori.'
speaker: the Italian peasant

utterance: 'Mrs. Wingate, then?'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'Fuori.'
speaker: the Italian peasant

utterance: 'There's only one road-the one by which I came up, A 291 and I haven't heard any carriage drive away; (6 if Fuori" means out, you are not telling the truth; they are not out, they are here.'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'Is there any one here who speaks English?'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'Ingleese? Si.'
speaker: the Italian peasant

utterance: 'I hear you wish to speak to me?'
speaker: the American convert

utterance: 'You're an American?'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'I'm glad of that.'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'Well, you're another, and I'm not glad of it! Americans are limited. Besides, they are Puritans. My being an American doesn't make any difference to you, that I know of.'
speaker: the American convert

utterance: 'Yes, it does. You come from a country where no one is shut up. Do you know Miss Bruce?'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'A little,'
speaker: the American convert

utterance: 'Take me to her.'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'I can't, she is in retreat.'
speaker: the American convert

utterance: 'You wouldn't approve of force being used for any one; I am sure you would not,'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'Force? Force is never used here, you must be out of your mind. If you do not see Miss Bruce, you may depend that it is because she does not wish to see you.'
speaker: the American convert

utterance: 'She would-if she could hear me say one word!'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'No doubt you'd cajole her! I'm glad she is where you can't get at her, poor dear!'
speaker: the American convert

utterance: 'She was to have been my wife two weeks ago,'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'Well, go home now; she'll never be your wife this side the grave,'
speaker: the American convert

utterance: 'I'll make all Italy ring with it, madam. This old house shall come down about your ears.'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'Mercy me! We're not Italians, we're English. And we've got a government protection; it's a charitable institution.'
speaker: the American convert

utterance: 'For inveigling people, and getting their money! Miss Bruce, you know, has money.'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'I didn't know a thing about it--not a thing! Money, has she? Well, Ernestine Wingate does like money; she wants to build a new wing. Look here, Father Ambrose is coming here to-day; you want to see him. He'll do what's right, he is a very good man; and he commands all the others; they have to do as he says, whether they like it or not. I guess you'd better not hurry away,'
speaker: the American convert

utterance: 'Are you going in?
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: That is what I have come for,'
speaker: Father Ambrose

utterance: 'Will you kindly tell me your business?'
speaker: Father Ambrose

utterance: 'It concerns Miss Bruce, an American who has only been here a few days. She came, supposing that the death of my brother was due to an act of hers; I have just learned that she is completely mistaken, he died from another cause.'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'God be praised! She has been very unhappy-very,'
speaker: Father Ambrose

utterance: 'I should like to see her. The whole community can be present, if you please.'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'That will hardly be necessary,'
speaker: Father Ambrose

utterance: 'I will tell her myself, I will go at once.'
speaker: Father Ambrose

utterance: 'I prefer to see her. You have no real authority over her, she has not yet taken the vows.'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'There has been no talk of vows,'
speaker: Father Ambrose

utterance: 'Every one is free here, I don't know what you are thinking of! If you will give me your address, Miss Bruce will write to you.'
speaker: Father Ambrose

utterance: 'Do you refuse to let me see her?'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'For the present-yes. You must remember that we don't know who you are.'
speaker: Father Ambrose

utterance: 'She will tell you.'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'Yes; she is very intelligent,'
speaker: Father Ambrose

utterance: 'Let me pass,'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'In a moment. All shall be as you like, if you will waiton.'
speaker: Mr. Smith

utterance: 'Wait yourself!'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'Now, no more violence! You'll hardly knock down a woman, I suppose?'
speaker: Mrs. Wingate

utterance: 'Forty, if necessary.'
speaker: Paul Tennant

utterance: 'No one has ever wished to prevent your entrance,'
speaker: Mrs. Wingate

utterance: 'Your violence has been unnecessary-the violence of a boor!'
speaker: Mrs. Wingate
